d0833ce1-711f-421f-92de-3e25fa94dc3c.text: You’re reading this on a screen, but you may want to take a break after finishing the article to avoid spending years of your life eyeballing pixels. That’s not hyperbole. Worldwide, internet users spend an average of 400 minutes—nearly seven hours—a day online, according to a new report.\nDigital reference library DataReportal <https://datareportal.com/> in January released its annual Global Overview Report <https://datareportal.com/reports/digital-2024-global-overview-report>, revealing internet users ages 16 to 64 spend an average six hours, 40 minutes daily surfing the web on any device <https://fortune.com/well/2023/03/03/healthier-habits-phone-screen-time-technology/>. That’s about 47 hours a week and 101 days a year. By this estimation, beginning at age 18, a person who lives to be 80 will have spent more than 17 years of their adult life using the internet <https://fortune.com/well/2022/09/16/children-spend-more-time-on-devices-now-experts-say-excessive-screen-time-may-be-a-risk-factor-for-early-puberty/?utm_source=search&utm_medium=suggested_search&utm_campaign=search_link_clicks>.

metadata.title: 17 years of your adult life may be spent online. These expert tips may help curb your screen time

8f7c0a75-a8f1-4b70-bbc6-effd6e6fecec.text: It’s worse in the U.S. <https://fortune.com/well/2023/07/19/how-to-cut-back-screen-time/>, with Americans spending an average seven hours, three minutes online a day—exceeding 18 years of their adult lives. People in Japan spend the least time online daily, three hours, 56 minutes, while those in South Africa spend the most, nine hours, 24 minutes. Between the ages of 18 and 80, that amounts to 10 and 24 years online, respectively.\n\nThe idea that people around the world spend the equivalent of their entire childhoods connected to the internet <https://fortune.com/well/article/smartphone-use-exercise-mental-health-workplace-well-being/> may be a disturbing thought. But a key step in coming to terms with the startling statistic is to embrace the inevitable, according to Alex Turvy, M.Ed. <https://ccc.tulane.edu/alex-turvy>, a researcher in Tulane University’s City + Culture + Community program <https://ccc.tulane.edu/> studying social media and internet culture.

As I sit here typing in San Francisco, things seem pretty normal. My laptop and Wi-Fi connection are working, and I’m chatting with colleagues via Slack. For the past 12 hours though, a huge swath of the planet was not so lucky. 

The outage, which apparently stemmed from a faulty software update from security provider CrowdStrike, set off a chain reaction that took down PCs and servers at airlines, TV stations, banks, hospitals, and countless other organizations. As Ars Technica noted <https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2024/07/major-outages-at-crowdstrike-microsoft-leave-the-world-with-bsods-and-confusion/>, “the problems started in Australia and followed the dateline from there.”

For those affected, it must have seemed like a scene straight out of one of the dystopian "End of Times" movies we love to watch.

"But this was the scene we all prepared for IRL on New Year's Eve 24 years ago, as the clocks on our computers struck midnight, and the last two digits of the year 1999 went back to zero to mark the start of a new millennium. If you think back to the Y2K prep days, the scenarios envisioned were very much like what happened today. 

“The Year 2000 problem could result in a stunning array of technological failures. Air traffic could be delayed or even grounded; telephone service could be interrupted; breakdowns in the production and distribution of electricity could bring widespread power failures; automatic teller machines might malfunction; traffic lights could stop working,” reads a 1998 report <https://www.congress.gov/105/crpt/hrpt827/CRPT-105hrpt827.pdf> by the Congressional Committee on Government Reform and Oversight.", mimetype='text/plain', start_char_idx=None, end_char_idx=None, text_template='{metadata_str}

At the time, Dr. Kabir said cardiologists were unable to review electrocardiograms, the critical tests that measure electrical activity of the heart. "I’d say most people have done it at least one or two times,” he said.

Ironically, hospitals and clinics are using companies like CrowdStrike specifically to avoid these sorts of shutdowns and bolster the safety of the often outdated tech systems they rely on. The CrowdStrike episode has underscored that system shutdowns may be unavoidable.

The healthcare industry is just one of many industry's slammed by the outage. The glitch has shaken the entire global economy—impacting everything from airlines to television stations to government agencies. “My morning started with a 4 a.m. call from the Situation Room to highlight the issue that occurred with CrowdStrike,” Anne Neuberger, Deputy Assistant to President Biden and Deputy National Security Advisor for cyber and emerging technologies, said on stage this morning at the Aspen Security Forum, when asked about the outage.

c2ae8865-7134-4d7f-a68f-69a5244fdcba.text:
Several adversarial nations have been known to use false (spoofed) GPS signals to interfere with air transit <https://australianaviation.com.au/2023/03/qantas-pilots-subject-to-gps-jamming-from-chinese-warships/>, shipping <https://www.lloydslist.com/LL1148748/War-zone-GPS-jamming-sees-more-ships-show-up-at-airports>, and trade <https://www.technologyreview.com/2019/11/15/131940/ghost-ships-crop-circles-and-soft-gold-a-gps-mystery-in-shanghai/>, or to disrupt military logistics in conflict zones. And recent discussions of anti-satellite weapons <https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cq55ww5j7e2o> renewed fears of deliberate actions designed to wreak economic havoc by knocking out GPS. 

GPS has become so ubiquitous in our daily lives that we hardly think about what happens when it’s not available

A GPS outage would result in many online services becoming unavailable (these rely on GPS-based network synchronization), failure of in-vehicle Satnav, and no location-based services on your mobile phone.

metadata.title: Reliable GPS is coming to an end—but new quantum technologies could show the path forward

a06d87ea-81df-4876-9245-f64b4a2f0d81.text: Past disruptions have been less severe. In 2017, a series of errors within Amazon <https://fortune.com/company/amazon-com/>.com Inc.’s cloud service affected <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-02-28/amazon-web-services-reports-high-error-rates-with-data-storage> the operation of tens of thousands of websites. In 2021, issues at content delivery network <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-08/website-outage-hits-reddit-news-u-k-government-pages> Fastly took out several media networks including Bloomberg News and there were separate disruptions at Amazon’s AWS cloud service <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/newsletters/2021-12-08/aws-resolved-its-outage-what-happens-now>.\n\n“I don’t think it’s too early to call it: this will be the largest IT outage in history,” Troy Hunt, an Australian security consultant and creator of the hack-checking website Have I Been Pwned, said in a post <https://x.com/troyhunt/statuses/1814198760387596407> on social media platform X.

metadata.title: Major Microsoft and Crowdstrike disruptions ground planes, banks, McDonald’s stores and the London Stock Exchange

That being said, some experts have shared their views on the potential performance of certain stocks and sectors in 2024.
622425dd-e623-4a55-814a-364be48b169a.txt.LLM_query: What are the best stock picks for 2024?

6c303604-c5af-4a9f-b62f-3dbb814720e7.text:
Americans faced many financial challenges this year, from persistent inflation to increasingly expensive debt. However, the stock market <https://fortune.com/recommends/investing/what-are-stocks/> was one area of the economy that saw improvement. 

After plunging more than 18% in 2022, the S&P 500 rallied over 24% in 2023. (Fun fact: Every time the S&P 500 has fallen more than 18% in a year, it has then posted at least two consecutive years of gains.)

Now the question is: Will this upward trajectory continue into 2024? And how can the average person get the most out of their investments next year? Here’s what experts say about what the stock market might do in 2024.

2024 stock market outlook

metadata.title: Stock market outlook for 2024: Here’s what the experts predict

4b91275f-205d-469a-b9cb-2f50ff2b027f.text: Mukherjee says that interest rates are likely to fall through the year as the Fed becomes less hawkish and inflation continues to decline alongside moderate economic growth. “However, rates should stay at higher levels relative to the pre-Covid era,” he says. Additionally, although cash yields are attractive for now, “the appeal of high-quality bonds <https://fortune.com/recommends/investing/what-are-bonds/> will increase as the economy slows, and on better diversification attributes to risk assets,” he adds.\nAnthony Denier, CEO of the trading platform Webull, says he believes the stock market will ultimately post a positive return in 2024 as investors anticipate interest rate cuts by the Fed. However, he adds, we probably won’t see as big of a rally as we did in 2023. “Typically, returns are muted in the last year of a president’s term,” he says.

metadata.title: The relentless stock market rally could pull off another shocker

f1609ed9-ed6e-43e3-8cce-c2800af05f6b.text:
AI chip supplier Nvidia <https://fortune.com/company/nvidia/> led the index <https://fortune.com/2024/06/05/nvidia-stock-apples-3-trillion-valuation/> with a 239% gain in 2023. Meta and Tesla <https://fortune.com/company/tesla/>, two other tech giants involved in AI, surged 194% and 102%, respectively, last year. Goldman Sachs <https://fortune.com/company/goldman-sachs-group/> estimates that AI investment could reach as high as $200 billion globally by 2025. 

The stock market gains that helped add so many millionaires in 2023 have persisted so far this year as the S&P 500 and the tech-heavy Nasdaq <https://fortune.com/company/nasdaq/> index hit record highs this week. The S&P 500 is up about 12% year-to-date and some of the biggest players in AI, like Nvidia and Microsoft <https://fortune.com/company/microsoft/>, have seen their shares continue to soar in 2024.

Correction, Jun. 11, 2024: This story has been updated with corrected figures for the number of new millionaires.

metadata.title: AI stock frenzy helps mint 500,000 millionaires in the U.S., trouncing the rest of the world

Which players are first-round favorites in the 2024 NFL Draft?

Quarterbacks should be in high demand this year. Caleb Williams from USC is expected to be scooped up first, but several other teams are looking for field generals as well. Other expected high-ranking picks could include:

metadata.title: How to watch the 2024 NFL Draft for free—and without cable

7c264a24-c066-49d1-b1f4-8b2790164269.text:
* Jayden Daniels, LSU – Daniels is a Heisman trophy winner and passed for 40 touchdowns last season. He’s expected to be one of the hottest picks in the draft. 
 * Drake Maye, UNC – Maye could easily be the second pick of the year, though it’s neck-and-neck with Daniels. Don’t be surprised if the Vikings try to maneuver an early trade to nab him, as Josh McCown was Maye’s coach in high school. 
 * Marvin Harrison Jr, Ohio State – Taking a quick break from the QB shuffle, Harrison is a wide receiver who likely won’t have to wait long to find a home in the NFL. He was widely considered the best receiver in college football last year. 
 * J. McCarthy, Michigan – After leading the Wolverines to a national championship last year, McCarthy is certain to be an early pick. 
What comes after the draft?

Once the draft is over, the 2024-2025 schedule is next on the agenda. That will be released in May. The season will begin on Thursday, September 5, wrapping up with Super Bowl LIX on Feb. 9.

Tickets will go on sale after the schedule is announced.

metadata.title: How to watch the 2024 NFL Draft for free—and without cable

6aafb4c1-17f6-4070-84b0-6aa41c6c04f6.text: And that was before the stock market set fresh record highs over the past week as new inflation data <https://fortune.com/2024/07/11/inflation-consumer-price-index-drop-interest-rate-cuts/> gave the Federal Reserve more leeway to cut rates in the near future and Fed Chairman Jerome Powell sounded increasingly dovish <https://fortune.com/2024/07/09/economic-outlook-fed-chair-jerome-powell-warns-inflation-risk/>.\n\nThe surge of interest in single stocks comes as stock-picking has been overshadowed by passive investing in recent years, with funds that track indexes like the S&P 500 drawing more and more capital while actively managed funds continue to underperform the market <https://fortune.com/2024/07/06/sp500-vs-actively-managed-funds-outperformance-buying-holding-passive-index-investing/>.

Top HR leaders from companies including Walmart and Estée Lauder reveal their New Year’s resolutions from AI adoption to ‘bringing more joy and energy into the workplace’
Top HR leaders from companies including Walmart and Estée Lauder reveal their New Year’s resolutions from AI adoption to ‘bringing more joy and energy into the workplace’

1df423c1-a34d-4566-9af7-6ddc0129a063.text:
Good morning!

Love them or hate them <https://fortune.com/well/2022/12/24/sheryl-lee-ralph-on-why-shes-ditching-new-years-resolutions-im-not-doing-it-anymore-im-just-gonna-be-my-best/>, New Year’s resolutions offer a chance for anyone to start the year with a clean slate and define their ambitions for the coming months. Business leaders are certainly no exception.

I reached out to the CHROs from 10 companies, including Estée Lauder, Papa Johns, and Walmart, asking them to share their hopes for 2024, and what they plan to focus their energies on. 

Their answers ran the gamut, from providing better support for middle managers, to concentrating on retaining talent. Several themes echoed across resolutions as a whole, including better investment into AI, emphasizing employee wellbeing, and improving employee learning and skills development. 

Cori Davis, the chief people officer at biotechnology company Genentech, took a big picture approach to her resolution, and noted that the last several years have been difficult for everyone. Her goal is to “bring more joy and energy into the workplace.”

metadata.title: HR leaders reveal their resolutions for 2024

e3c36f89-192a-4e93-a9d9-390a0e09a39c.text:
In that regard, index funds are still king <https://fortune.com/2024/07/29/wall-street-burt-malkiel-biggest-investing-mistakes/>. And a broad-based fund solves the problem of picking sectors as well, because they give meaningful exposure to the sectors producing the best returns. 

“The beauty of owning a broad index is that you’re likely to get exposure to that AI winner in your portfolio anyway,” he writes.

Rather than trying to pick stocks, Malkiel encourages investors to focus on what they can control, including the cost of their investments. Keep fund fees and taxes minimal, and that will have more of a positive effect long-term on their performance.

“The long-run way to build wealth is to just keep on going,” he says.

This story was originally featured on Fortune.com <https://fortune.com/2024/07/30/tech-stocks-wild-ride-makes-the-case-for-index-fund-investing-says-wall-street-guru-burt-malkiel/>

metadata.title: Tech stocks’ wild ride makes the case for index-fund investing, says Wall Street guru Burt Malkiel

dc47cfbe-5719-4e63-bc04-7b135bf84733.txt.LLM_answer: With a budget of $50k, you have a wide range of options for a used family car. Since you're looking for a family car, I'll assume you're prioritizing reliability, safety, and space. According to Consumer Reports, Toyota and Lexus are consistently ranked as the most reliable car brands [1]. In fact, the Toyota RAV4 is a popular choice for families, and it's known for its spacious interior and strong resale value [4]. You can find a used 2020 or 2021 Toyota RAV4 within your budget.

c17ac4b8-1c1e-4e12-bb0a-9306757f4a05.text:
For the first time in its history, Consumer Reports is offering used-car shoppers its picks on the best makes and models.

The company, which has traditionally only offered top picks for new cars, said the decision to offer the new listing was in recognition of the historically high price of new cars and the fact that more and more people are focusing on pre-owned options these days.

“They shouldn’t have to sacrifice safety, reliability, or fuel economy to stay within their budget,” said Alex Knizek, manager of automotive testing and insights for Consumer Reports <https://www.consumerreports.org/cars/best-used-cars-of-the-year-10-top-picks-a8027733372/>. “That’s why we created these Used Car Top Picks and are expanding our used-car coverage and insights.”

The magazine kept the picks under $20,000—and noted that a great new car isn’t necessarily a great used one, given factors like depreciation and long-term reliability. It also warned people to have the car inspected before purchasing, even if they went with a Consumer Reports pick.

metadata.title: Consumer Reports ranks the most reliable used cars for the first time

metadata.title: Used EV prices have fallen far below gas vehicles

44b8f115-3670-4f80-b6b0-3007e383f473.text: As recently as last year, it was hard to find a new electric car for less than $50,000 <https://fortune.com/2024/01/25/what-electric-vehicles-cost-less-than-50000-dollars-2024-cheap-evs/>. But over the past few months, automakers have cut prices <https://fortune.com/2024/02/21/tesla-price-cuts-driving-down-car-values-ev-makers-sending-checks-leasing-firms-compensate-them/>; the used market has helped fill the gap for budget-conscious buyers <https://www.recurrentauto.com/research/used-electric-vehicle-buying-report>; and new tax incentives are allowing dealers to cut up to $4,000 off the sticker price of some used and leased EVs at the point of sale—bringing prices down even further.

metadata.title: The cost of buying a used electric car is plummeting—and that’s great news for mass adoption, but bad news if you already bought one

a6ad11dc-7c1e-4eb0-ba17-5f30c979ba37.text: Amid a 19.6% price increase <https://perc.tamu.edu/blog/2024/02/price-trends-for-cars.html#:~:text=The%20price%20of%20new%20vehicles,increased%2018%25%20since%20January%202021.> of automobiles from January 2021 to 2024, most of these compact SUVs are under $30,000, with many under $25,000—a stark difference from the $60,000 price tag <https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimgorzelany/2023/09/29/heres-how-much-pickup-truck-prices-skyrocketed-during-the-pandemic-era/> of a pickup truck and an easier-to-swallow pill. Often with lower interest rates <https://www.cnn.com/cnn-underscored/money/auto-loan-interest-rates-by-credit-score> than even gently used cars and similar features to their larger counterparts, smaller vehicles have become a formidable alternative.

metadata.title: Small cars are back because that’s all Americans can afford

f8b6f271-12f7-4f90-8eb3-75569d08af1c.text: But the industry will continue to make changes to appeal to those looking for compact, affordable cars. Moody notes that the No. 4 best-selling car below the top-three pickup juggernauts is the stalwart Toyota <https://fortune.com/company/toyota-tsusho/> Rav 4, which led the trend of compact SUVs after its introduction 30 years ago <https://www.millertoyota.com/2-full-decades-of-rav4-history/>. He expects the compact Toyota model to continue to creep up <https://www.roadandtrack.com/reviews/a60688493/2024-toyota-rav4-trd-off-road-first-drive/> the rankings as compact cars continue to rise in popularity. \n\nMoody also expects more hybrid compact SUVs to emerge, particularly as an alternative to electric vehicles, which, because of their large and heavy batteries <https://www.axios.com/2023/04/28/evs-weight-safety-problems>, are often oversized and expensive. Even EV producers are aware of the pitfalls of large electric cars, and they’re aiming to produce smaller autos.

1712fab3-dc85-4e07-977f-ef8f3d21c115.text: to sixty miles per hour in anywhere from eight and a half to ten and a half seconds and through the quarter-mile in seventeen seconds to a speed of about eighty—performance that outshines other small sedans, many sports cars, and quite a few big V-8-powered cars. Top speed is 110 or more. At highway passing speeds the car leaps ahead where others run out of breath. But the performance seems even stronger than it is because of the car\'s uncanny freedom from noise and vibration. Only a few luxury cars offer comparable sensations; with windows rolled up, the loudest sounds at seventy-five miles per hour are wind noise and the whine of transmission gears. The car does have its drawbacks. Drivers must learn to heed their tachometers, since the engine climbs so easily to high revolutions. Although the four-speed transmission is smooth, with gear ranges well suited to U.S. driving conditions, a stiff and "grabby" clutch exacerbates the problem of starting smoothly from a dead stop. Those who want automatic transmissions will have to wait until later this year. Owners have also complained that gas mileage, which averages between eighteen and twenty-three miles per gallon, is poor for a small car, and oil consumption averaging 1,400 miles a quart
